March 15, 2015: Fiction
THE GIRL ON THE TRAIN, by Paula Hawkins. (Riverhead.) A psychological
thriller set in London.
ALL THE LIGHT WE CANNOT SEE, by Anthony Doerr. (Scribner.) The lives of a
blind French girl and a gadget-obsessed German boy before and during World
War II.
MIGHTIER THAN THE SWORD, by Jeffrey Archer. (St. Martin's.) In the fifth
volume of the Clifton Chronicles, Harry Clifton becomes president of English PEN
and works to free a Soviet writer.
PRODIGAL SON, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte.) Twins, one good and one bad,
reunite after 20 years when one of them returns to their hometown. But it is no
longer clear who the good and who the bad one is.
A SPOOL OF BLUE THREAD, by Anne Tyler. (Knopf.) Four generations of a
family are drawn to a house in the Baltimore suburbs.
THE NIGHTINGALE, by Kristin Hannah. (St. Martin's.) Two sisters in World War II
France: one struggling to survive in the countryside, the other joining the
Resistance in Paris.
THE WHITES, by Richard Price writing as Harry Brandt. (Holt.) A slashing in Penn
Station draws a Manhattan detective back into a case from the past that haunts
him.
GRAY MOUNTAIN, by John Grisham. (Doubleday.) In a small Virginia town, a
downsized Wall Street lawyer becomes involved in litigation against the mining
industry.
TRIGGER WARNING, by Neil Gaiman. (Morrow/HarperCollins.) Stories and
poems about the power of imagination.
OBSESSION IN DEATH, by J. D. Robb. (Putnam.) A murderer is obsessed with
Lt. Eve Dallas; by Nora Roberts, writing pseudonymously.
PRIVATE VEGAS, by James Patterson and Maxine Paetro. (Little, Brown.) Jack
Morgan, the head of an investigative firm, uncovers a murder ring in Las Vegas.
THE ACCIDENTAL EMPRESS, by Allison Pataki. (Howard Books.) The Austro-
Hungarian emperor Franz Joseph’s spirited young wife navigates the treacherous
imperial court.
DOUBLE FUDGE BROWNIE MURDER, by Joanne Fluke. (Kensington.) In Lake
Eden, Minn., the baker Hannah Swensen becomes a suspect in the murder of a
judge; recipes included.
March 15, 2015
Non-Fiction
BEING MORTAL, by Atul Gawande. (Metropolitan/Holt.) The surgeon and New
Yorker writer considers how doctors fail patients at the end of life, and offers
suggestions for how they can do better; the subject of a PBS documentary.
GIRL IN A BAND, by Kim Gordon. (Dey Street/Morrow.) A memoir by a founding
member of Sonic Youth.
FUTURE CRIMES, by Marc Goodman. (Doubleday.) The world of cybercrime and
corporate spying, and advice on protecting yourself.
KILLING PATTON, by Bill O'Reilly and Martin Dugard. (Holt.) The host of “The
O’Reilly Factor” recounts the death of Gen. George S. Patton in December 1945.
H IS FOR HAWK, by Helen Macdonald. (Grove.) Overwhelmed by her father’s
death, a British woman decides to raise a goshawk, a bird that is fierce and
notoriously difficult to tame.
YES PLEASE, by Amy Poehler. (Dey Street/Morrow.) A humorous miscellany from
the comedian and actress.
BELIEVER, by David Axelrod. (Penguin Press.) A memoir by the political
consultant who became Barack Obama’s campaign strategist and White House
adviser.
WHAT IF?, by Randall Munroe. (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt.) Scientific (but often
humorous) answers to hypothetical questions, based in part on the author’s
website, xkcd.com.
SPRING CHICKEN, by Bill Gifford. (Grand Central.) A review of the science of —
and myths about — aging, and advice on how to live longer.
RED NOTICE, by Bill Browder. (Simon & Schuster.) A successful American hedge
fund manager in Russia was expelled by kleptocrats who then seized his property.
I AM MALALA, by Malala Yousafzai with Christina Lamb. (Little, Brown.) The
experience of the young Pakistani advocate for women’s education who was shot
by the Taliban and later won the Nobel Peace Prize.
LEAVING BEFORE THE RAINS COME, by Alexandra Fuller. (Penguin Press.) A
memoir of a marriage’s collapse, by the author of “Don’t Let’s Go to the Dogs
Tonight” and "Cocktail Hour Under the Tree of Forgetfulness."
IT'S WHAT I DO, by Lynsey Addario. (Penguin Press.) A photojournalist who
shared a Pulitzer for her work describes her experience covering wars.
SAPIENS, by Yuval Noah Harari. (Harper.) How Homo sapiens became Earth’s
dominant species.
